title: 109_s1600
content:
The title of the act is the "Digital Translator and Low-Power Television Transition Assistance Act." The deadline for the conversion of translator stations and low-power analog television stations is specified in the act. The act specifies a 4-year transition period for digital television, amending relevant sections of the Communications Act of 1934. The Low-power Digital Television Transition Trust Fund is established to be administered by the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information. Proceeds from the auction of channels 52 through 69 on the electromagnetic spectrum will contribute to the fund. The Transition Assistance Act establishes the Low-power Digital Television Transition Trust Fund with a cap of $100,000,000. The Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information will oversee a grant program for upgrading low-power television stations from analog to digital in eligible rural communities. The Transition Assistance Act establishes a grant program overseen by the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for upgrading low-power television stations from analog to digital in eligible rural communities. The program aims to extend digital television broadcast signals to unserved households in eligible rural communities and other areas. The Assistant Secretary will establish a notification and application procedure, along with conditions and assurances to ensure program efficiency and integrity. The Low-power Digital Television Transition Fund allows grants for upgrading low-power television stations from analog to digital in eligible rural communities. Eligible licensees include low-power television station licensees or low-power television translator stations. Unused funds revert to the general fund after the transition period. Within 6 months of this Act's enactment, the FCC must provide a report to Congress on the status of low-power television and television translator stations. Additionally, there is a provision for an International Coordination Study in Title II. SEC. 201. INTERNATIONAL COORDINATION STUDY.

Starting February 1, 2006, the FCC must provide reports every 6 months to Congress on the progress of international coordination with Canada and Mexico regarding the DTV table of allotments.
